titlestmt.titleproper: Latin American Labor Movements collection of newspapers
Finding Aid for the collection of newspapers published by Latin American Labor Movements, 1892-1967 LSC.1425
titlestmt.author: Processed by Octavio Olvera, May 2012; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cubé.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-01-05 12:38:28 -0800.

did.unittitle: Collection of newspapers published by Latin American Labor Movements
did.abstract: A collection of newspapers published by Latin American labor movement.
did.physloc: Stored off-site at SRLF. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. Please contact UCLA Library Special Collections for paging information.
did.langmaterial: Finding aid is written in English.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. STORED OFF-SITE AT SRLF. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. Please contact UCLA Library Special Collections for paging information.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical object belong to the UC Regents. Literary rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Collection of Newspapers Published by Latin American Labor Movements (Collection 1425). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.
